title: In the previous activities you solved few problems on searching algorithms. In this activity  also there are few more questions please answer those questions

questions.questionText: What is the smallest value that num can be such that the number 3 is printed?

Now, we redefine L to be:
L = [2, 0, 1, 5, 3, 4]
What is the smallest value that num can be such that the number 3 is printed?

options.feedback:
When L = [5, 0, 2, 4, 6, 3, 1], we need to set num = 1 to get 3 to print out.
When L = [2, 0, 1, 5, 3, 4], there is no way to get to the number 3 if we start from val = 0, because the indirection structure for L is (0->2->1->0, 3->5->4->3).

When L = [5, 0, 2, 4, 6, 3, 1], we need to set num = 1 to get 3 to print out.
When L = [2, 0, 1, 5, 3, 4], there is no way to get to the number 3 if we start from val = 0, because the indirection structure for L is (0->2->1->0, 3->5->4->3).

When L = [5, 0, 2, 4, 6, 3, 1], we need to set num = 1 to get 3 to print out.
When L = [2, 0, 1, 5, 3, 4], there is no way to get to the number 3 if we start from val = 0, because the indirection structure for L is (0->2->1->0, 3->5->4->3).

When L = [5, 0, 2, 4, 6, 3, 1], we need to set num = 1 to get 3 to print out.
When L = [2, 0, 1, 5, 3, 4], there is no way to get to the number 3 if we start from val = 0, because the indirection structure for L is (0->2->1->0, 3->5->4->3).
